'''Rust Heinz''' (October 18, 1914 – July 24, 1939) was famed for designing the 1938 [[Phantom Corsair]], a prototype car built on a Cord 810 chassis by the coach builder [[Bohman & Schwartz]], incorporated a Lycoming 190bhp [[V8 engine]], weighed two tons and had seating capacity for six people.
The Phantom Corsair project which was helped by finance from his aunt. Following his death was never mass produced and the [[prototype]] remains the only one ever made.
== Background == Heinz was born in 1914 in [[Pittsburgh]], Pennsylvania.<ref>[http://www.moaaad.org/artistlink.php?artist=Heinz Museum of Automobile Art & Design]</ref> He was the second son of Howard Covode Heinz and Elizabeth Granger Heinz and grandson of the late [[Henry J. Heinz]] who founded the Heinz empire and was the brother of Henry [[Jack Heinz|John "Jack" Heinz, II]]. In 1937 he married Helen Clay Goodloe, and together had a daughter Helen Meredith Dewitt Heinz.
Heinz started out studying [[Naval architecture|Naval Architecture]] at [[Yale University]]<ref>{{cite web | url=https://automotiveviews.com/2011/11/10/icon-the-phantom-corsair/ | title=The Deco Dream – Rust Heinz's Phantom Corsair| date=2011-11-10}}</ref> and Westlawn Academy of Yacht Design <ref>{{cite web | url=http://theoldmotor.com/?p=155989 | title=“Wombat” or Not, the 1938 Phantom Corsair is Spectacular| date=2016-03-21}}</ref>and designing a number of [[speedboats]],<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.classicandsportscar.com/news/csc-features/the-incredible-story-of-the-futuristic-phantom-corsair | title=The incredible story of the futuristic Phantom Corsair| date=2013-06-21}}</ref> and abandoned his studies in 1936 went to live with his aunt in [[Pasadena, California|Pasadena]], and set up a design studio and established himself as an automobile designer in California, realising a passion he held since 1936 when he was 21 years old, first designing a delivery vehicle called the Comet for the Heinz company which was built by the Square Deal Body Company on an Autocar chassis intended to be used for promotional work,<ref>{{cite web | url=https://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/03/05/a-dream-car-makes-an-appearance/ | title=A Dream Car Makes an Appearance| date=2009-03-05}}</ref> and then designing the Phantom Corsair.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kustomrama.com/index.php?title=The_Phantom_Corsair|title=The Phantom Corsair - Kustomrama|website=www.kustomrama.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-23}}</ref>
== Death == Heinz was killed on July 24, 1939 in a car accident at Westinghouse Bridge in Wilkinsburg, Pennsylvania. Heinz had allowed his friend Phil Brainard to drive his open Buick home from a dance he was attending with friends, and during the journey Brainard’s hat flew off. After a detour to collect the trilby, the Buick ventured back on to the [[Lincoln Highway]] near [[Versailles, Pennsylvania|Versailles]] and was broadsided by an unseen vehicle. Six people were injured in the crash and Heinz died the following morning from head injuries.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.classicandsportscar.com/news/csc-features/the-incredible-story-of-the-futuristic-phantom-corsair | title=The incredible story of the futuristic Phantom Corsair| date=2013-06-21}}</ref>
Heinz is buried at [[Homewood Cemetery]], [[Pittsburgh]], Pennsylvania.<ref>[http://www.interment.net/data/us/pa/allegheny/the-homewood-cemetery/records-hat-hep.htm Interment.net]</ref>

The '''Saunders family''' was a family of important [[industrialist]]s and politicians in [[New England]].
==Daniel Saunders Sr.== {{ external media | align = right | image1 = [http://queencityma.files.wordpress.com/2010/11/saunders1.jpg] }} '''Daniel Saunders Sr.''' (June 20, 1796 – October 8, 1872) was born in [[Salem, New Hampshire]]. His youth was spent in both Salem and [[Canada]]. He entered the textile industry as a teen-aged apprentice. After a stint as foreman at the [[Abbott Mills]] in [[Andover, Massachusetts]], he became connected with [[North Andover Mills]]. Then Saunders built his own small mill in Andover, and in 1840 he purchased mills in [[Concord, New Hampshire]]. In 1843 he sold the [[New Hampshire]] mills and the one in Andover in preparation for an even bigger enterprise. Daniel Saunders' new textile mill near Andover was the foundation for the new city of [[Lawrence, Massachusetts]]. Daniel Sr. was also rumored to have been involved in the [[Underground Railroad]]. The Daniel Saunders Elementary School is named after him.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Daniel Saunders Sr. (1796–1872) Lawrence, MA « Queen City Massachusetts|url=http://queencityma.wordpress.com/2010/11/02/daniel-saunders-sr-1796-1872-lawrence-ma|accessdate=2010-04-03}}</ref>
==Daniel Saunders Jr.== '''Daniel Saunders Jr.''' was a son of Daniel Saunders Sr. He married a Mary Livermore (not [[Mary Livermore]]), granddaughter of [[Samuel Livermore]]. Daniel Jr. was a [[lawyer]] and the 6th mayor of Lawrence, from 1860 to 1861, as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]].
==Caleb Saunders== '''Caleb Saunders''' was a son of Daniel Saunders Sr. He was the 19th mayor of Lawrence in 1877, as a Democrat.
==Charles W. Saunders== '''Charles Wesley Saunders''' (d. 1891) was a son of Daniel Saunders Sr. and the son-in-law of [[Jonathan Norcross#Nicholas Gaubert Norcross|Nicholas Gaubert Norcross]].
==Charles G. Saunders== '''Charles Gurley Saunders''' (ca. 1848–1918) was the son of Daniel Saunders Jr.
==Edith Saunders== Edith Saunders was one of three daughters of Daniel Saunders Jr. She was the last surviving member of this influential family.
==Grafton County Lumber Company== Daniel Jr. and Charles W. founded the Grafton County Lumber Company in 1874. While the company office and sales department was in [[Boston]], the logging operations centered about [[Livermore, New Hampshire]] and included the [[Sawyer River Railroad]] and a large [[sawmill]]. Indeed, every building in Livermore belonged to the Saunders, along with 30,000 acres of timberland. Daniel gave up his share in the company in 1880 to his son Charles G. After the death of Charles G. Saunders, the inheritance passed to his three sisters. Logging and sawmill operations continued until 1928, and the mostly-logged out land was sold to the [[U.S. Forest Service]] in 1935.

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} [[File:Habursa 2.JPG|250px|thumb|right|[[Diamond Exchange District]] in [[Ramat Gan]]]] [[File:Azorim Park PT.jpg|250px|thumb|right|Azorim High-Tech park in [[Petah-Tikva]]]] [[File:StartupVillage-Yokneam_03.jpg|250px|thumb|[[Yokneam Illit|Yokneam]]'s Startup Village High-Tech park ]] [[File:Matam hi-tech park (Haifa).jpg|250px|thumb|[[Matam, Haifa|Matam]] High-Tech park in [[Haifa]] ]] [[File:Israel Batch 3 (416).JPG|thumb|250px|right|[[Microsoft|Microsoft House]] in [[Herzliya]]]] [[File:Park Azorim 024.jpg|thumb|250px|right|[[Intel]] building in [[Petah Tikva]]]] [[File:IBM building Petax Tikva 201203 02.jpg|thumb|250px|right|[[IBM]] building in [[Petah Tikva]]]] '''Silicon Wadi'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/090e5dd2-e88e-11db-b2c3-000b5df10621.html?nclick_check=1|title=Business as usual|work=Financial Times}}</ref> ({{lang-he|סיליקון ואדי}}, [[literal translation|lit]]: "Silicon Valley") is an area with a high concentration of high-technology companies on the [[Israeli coastal plain|coastal plain]] of [[Israel]], similar to [[Silicon Valley]] in the [[U.S. state]] of [[California]], and is the reason Israel is nicknamed the Start-Up Nation.<ref>[http://www.concierge.com/cntraveler/articles/500770?pageNumber=3 Viva Tel Aviv!] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110825041504/http://www.concierge.com/cntraveler/articles/500770?pageNumber=3 |date=25 August 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |title=World On Fire |last=Chua |first= Amy |publisher=Knopf Doubleday Publishing |year=2003 |isbn=978-0385721868 |pages=219-220}}</ref> The area covers much of the country, although especially high concentrations of high-tech industry can be found in the area around [[Tel Aviv]], including small clusters around the cities of [[Ra'anana]], [[Petah Tikva]], [[Herzliya]], [[Netanya]], the academic city of [[Rehovot]] and its neighbour [[Rishon Le Zion]]. In addition, high-tech clusters can be found in [[Haifa]] and [[Caesarea, Israel|Caesarea]]. More recent high-tech establishments have been raised in [[Jerusalem]], and in towns such as [[Yokneam Illit]] and Israel's first "private city," Airport City, near Tel Aviv.
==Origin of the term== Silicon Wadi is a pun based on the [[California]]n region of [[Silicon Valley]]. "[[Wadi]]" is the Arabic word for a valley or dry river bed, also commonly used in colloquial [[Hebrew]].
==History== Israeli high-tech firms originally began to form in the 1960s.<ref name="report" /> In 1961 [[ECI Telecom]] was founded, followed in 1962 by [[Tadiran]] and [[Elron Electronic Industries]] regarded by many to be the "Fairchild of Israel."<ref name="report" /> The number of internationally successful firms grew slowly, with only one or two new successful firms each year until the early 1990s. [[Motorola]] was the first US corporation to set up an R&D unit in Israel, in 1964.<ref name="report" /> The center initially developed wireless products including remote irrigation systems and later developed leading chips such as the 68030.<ref name="report" /> Following the 1967 French arms embargo, Israel was forced to develop a domestic military industry, focusing on developing a technological edge over its neighbors.<ref name="report" /> Some of these military firms started to seek and develop civilian applications of military technology.<ref name="report" /> In the 1970s more commercial innovations began, many of which were based on military R&D, including: [[Scitex]] digital printing systems, which were based on fast rotation drums from fast-rotation electronic warfare systems,<ref name="report" /> and [[Elscint]], which developed innovative [[medical imaging]] and became a leading force in its market.<ref name=fu>[http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/Elscint-Ltd-Company-History.html Elscint Ltd. - Company history] FundingUniverse</ref>
High-tech firms continued to struggle throughout this period with marketing and many products, such as a mini-computer developed in the 1970s by [[Elbit]], who were unable to successfully commercialise the product.<ref name="report" />
===World software market takes off=== Slowly, the international computing industry shifted the emphasis from hardware (in which Israel had no comparative advantage) to software products (in which human capital plays a larger role).<ref name="report" /> The country became one of the first nations to compete in global software markets.<ref name="report" /> By the 1980s a diverse set of software firms had developed. Each found niches which were not dominated by US firms and between 1984 and 1991 "pure" software exports increased from $5 million to $110 million. Many of the important ideas here were developed by graduates of [[Mamram]], the Israeli computer corps, established by the [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] in the 1960s.<ref name="report" />
During the 1980s and early 1990s several successful software companies emerged from Israel, including: [[Amdocs]] (established in 1982 as Aurec Information), [[Cimatron]] (established in 1982), [[Magic Software Enterprises]] (established in 1983), [[Comverse]] (established in 1983 as Efrat Future Technologies), [[Aladdin Knowledge Systems]] (established in 1985), [[NICE Systems]] (established in 1986), [[Mercury Interactive]] (established in 1989) and [[Check Point|Check Point Software Technologies]] (established in 1993).
The 1990s saw the real takeoff of high-tech industries in Israel, with international media attention increasing awareness of innovation in the country.<ref name="report" /> Growth increased, whilst new [[Aliyah from the Soviet Union in the 1990s|immigrants from the Soviet Union]] increased the available high-tech workforce.<ref name="report" /> Peace agreements including the 1993 [[Oslo Peace Accord]] increased the investment environment and Silicon Wadi began to develop into a noticeable high-tech cluster.<ref name="report" />
===Dot-com boom=== In 1998, Mirabilis, an [[Israel]]i company that developed the [[ICQ]] [[instant messaging]] program, which revolutionized communication over the Internet,<ref>[http://english.themarker.com/47-yair-goldfinger-serial-entrepreneur-an-intensely-private-technology-angel-1.382778 Yair Goldfinger, serial entrepreneur / An intensely private technology angel, [[The Marker]] ]{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> was purchased by [[America Online]] (AOL) for $407 million in cash, 18 months after it was founded and having no revenues. The free service attracted a user base of 15 million in that period and by 2001, ICQ had over 100 million users worldwide.<ref>{{cite news|title=Is the ICQ experiment working?|url=http://news.cnet.com/2100-1023-257294.html|newspaper=CNET News|date=9 May 2001}}</ref>
The success of Mirabilis triggered the [[dot-com boom]] in Israel; thousands of start-up companies were established between 1998 and 2001, while [[venture capital]] raised by Israeli companies reached $1,851 million in 1999, peaking at $3,701 million in 2000. Over fifty Israeli companies had [[initial public offering]]s on [[NASDAQ]] and other international stock markets during that period.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/41/56/2491258.pdf|title=Page not found|work=oecd.org}}</ref>
===Silicon Wadi today=== For more than 50 years, local demand fueled Israeli industrial expansion, as the country's population grew rapidly and the standard of living rose. More recently, world demand for Israeli advanced technologies, software, electronics, and other sophisticated equipment has stimulated industrial growth. Israel's high status in new technologies is the result of its emphasis on [[higher education]] and research and development. Cultural factors contributing to the expansion includes [[chutzpah]] and openness to immigration.<ref>Chutzpah of Israeli Startups, {{cite web |url=http://radoff.com/blog/2009/12/05/chutzpah-of-israeli-startups/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=5 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091208121328/http://radoff.com/blog/2009/12/05/chutzpah-of-israeli-startups/ |archivedate=8 December 2009 }}</ref> The government also assists industrial growth by providing low-rate loans from its development budget. The main limitations experienced by industry are the scarcity of domestic raw materials and sources of energy and the restricted size of the local market. One certain advantage is that many Israeli university graduates are likely to become IT entrepreneurs or join startups, about twice as much as US university graduates, who are also attracted to traditional corporate executive positions, according to [[Charles A. Holloway]], co-director of the [[Center for Entrepreneurial Studies]] and a professor at the [[Stanford Graduate School of Business]] of [[Stanford University]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.jewishsf.com/content/2-0-/module/displaystory/story_id/13769/edition_id/266/format/html/displaystory.html|title=Silicon Wadi not that far from Silicon Valley, prof says|work=[[j.]]|first=Buzzy|last=Gordon|date=26 May 2000|accessdate=4 January 2012}}</ref> [[ICQ]], for instance, is one of the world's most famous Israeli software products, developed by 4 young entrepreneurs.<ref>[http://jobcircle.com/career/articles/x/njtc/2934.xml New Jersey Technology Council] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928213113/http://jobcircle.com/career/articles/x/njtc/2934.xml |date=28 September 2007 }}</ref> IBM has its IBM Content Discovery Engineering Team in Jerusalem,<ref name="IBM Research | IBM Haifa Labs">[http://www.haifa.il.ibm.com/jerusalem_facility.html IBM Research | IBM Haifa Labs] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070701012401/http://www.haifa.il.ibm.com/jerusalem_facility.html |date=1 July 2007 }}</ref> which is part of a number of [[IBM R&D Labs in Israel]].
===Genealogical research=== According to research conducted by Prof. Shmuel Ellis, Chair of the Management Department at [[Tel Aviv University]]'s Faculty of Management, together with Prof. Israel Drori of the School of Business Administration at the College of Management and Prof. Zur Shapira, Chair of the Management and Organizations Department at [[New York University]], the [[RAD Group]], founded in 1981 by brothers Yehuda and [[Zohar Zisapel]], has been "the most fertile ground" for creating Israeli entrepreneurs, having produced 56 "serial entrepreneurs" who established more than one start-up each. [[RAD Group]] "graduates" were responsible for the establishment of a total of 111 significant high-tech initiatives.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Mother of the Start-Ups: The RAD Group Gave Birth to 110 Companies|newspaper=The Marker|date=18 January 2012}}</ref>
==Location== [[File:TechnologyGarden.JPG|thumb|250px|The [[Jerusalem Technology Park]]]] [[File:PikiWiki Israel 16203 kiryat gat.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Hewlett-Packard|HP]], [[Intel]] and [[Micron Technology|Micron]] production plants in [[Kiryat Gat]]]] Due to the small size of Israel, the concentration of high-tech firms across much of the country is enough for it to be recognised as one large cluster. Most activity is located in the densely populated areas of metropolitan [[Tel Aviv]], [[Haifa]] ([[Matam, Haifa|Matam]]), and Jerusalem ([[Jerusalem Technology Park|Technology Park, Malha]], [[Har Hotzvim]] and [[Jerusalem Venture Partners|JVP Media Quarter]] in [[Talpiot]]), and the [[Startup Village, Yokneam|Startup Village Ecosystem in the Yokneam area]], although some secondary with additional activity include the corridor to [[Beer Sheba]], including [[Kiryat Gat]], and the Western Galilee. In all, this is an area no larger than 6000 square kilometers, half of the extended Silicon Valley's geographical coverage.<ref name="report">Catherine de Fontenay and Erran Carmel, [http://www.mbs.edu/home/defontenay/IsraelSiliconWadiJune2002.pdf Israel’s Silicon Wadi: The forces behind cluster formation], June 2002</ref>
==Economy== Many international technology companies have [[research and development]] facilities in this region, including companies such as [[Intel]], [[IBM]],<ref name="IBM Research | IBM Haifa Labs"/> [[Google]], [[Facebook]], [[Hewlett-Packard]], [[Philips]], [[Cisco Systems]], [[Oracle Corporation]], [[SAP AG|SAP]], [[BMC Software]], [[Microsoft]], [[Motorola]] and [[CA, Inc.|CA]]. Many Israeli high-tech companies are based in the region, including [[Zoran Corporation]], [[CEVA, Inc.]], [[Aladdin Knowledge Systems]], [[Mellanox]], [[NICE Systems]], Horizon Semiconductors, [[RAD Data Communications]], [[Radwin|RADWIN]], [[Radware]], [[Tadiran Telecom]], [[Radvision Ltd.|Radvision]], [[Check Point|Check Point Software Technologies]], [[Amdocs]], [[Babylon (program)|Babylon Ltd.]], [[Elbit]], [[Israel Aerospace Industries]] and the solar thermal equipment designer and manufacturer [[Solel]], with most of them being listed on the [[NASDAQ]], which even has an Israel Index. Intel developed its [[dual-core]] [[Intel Core 2|Core Duo]] processor at its Israel Development Center located at the ''Merkaz Ta'asiya ve'Meida'' ([[Matam, Haifa|Matam - Scientific Industries Center]]) in the city of [[Haifa]].<ref>[http://www.isrealli.org/israel-saves-intel Israel Saves Intel] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070824020303/http://www.isrealli.org/israel-saves-intel |date=24 August 2007 }}</ref> In 2006, more than 3,000 [[startup company|start-ups]] were created in Israel, a number that is only second to the US.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/090e5dd2-e88e-11db-b2c3-000b5df10621.html|title=Business as usual|work=Financial Times}}</ref> [[Newsweek Magazine]] has also named [[Tel Aviv]] as one of the world's top ten "Hot High-Tech Cities".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.israelemb.org/chicago/newsleter.htm|title=Error-2010-f3|work=israelemb.org}}</ref> In 1998, [[Tel Aviv]] was named by ''[[Newsweek]]'' as one of the ten technologically most influential cities in the world.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Economy/telaviv.html |title=Tel Aviv One of The World’s Top High-Tech Centers |work=Jewish Virtual Library |publisher=American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise |accessdate=14 October 2012}}</ref> In 2012, the city was also named one of the best places for high-tech startup companies, placed only second behind its [[Silicon Valley|California counterpart]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://go.bloomberg.com/tech-deals/2012-11-21-after-silicon-valley-tel-aviv-ranks-best-for-tech-startups-study/ | work=Bloomberg | title=After Silicon Valley, Tel Aviv Ranks Best for Tech Startups: Study}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://israel21c.org/news/tel-aviv-named-top-startup-center/|title=Tel Aviv named top startup center|work=ISRAEL21c}}</ref>
===Importance=== The importance of Silicon Wadi was first recognised internationally by Wired magazine, who in 2000, ranked locations by the strength of cluster effects, giving the Israeli high-tech cluster the same rank as Boston, Helsinki, London, and Kista in Sweden, second only to Silicon Valley.
===Sectors=== * A cluster of software companies, who are monetizing "free" software downloads by [[adware]] or altering user's systems, has been dubbed [[Download Valley]].<ref name=Inbal>{{cite news |last1=Hirschauge |first1=Orr |title=Conduit Diversifies Away From 'Download Valley' |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/conduit-seeks-diversifies-away-from-download-valley-1400152825?tesla=y |accessdate=5 September 2018 |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=May 15, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Orpaz |first1=Inbal |last2=Smolsky |first2=Raz |title=Amazon to Expand Its Operations in Israel |url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/business/.premium-amazon-to-expand-its-operations-in-israel-1.5371061 |accessdate=5 September 2018 |work=Haaretz |date=June 11, 2015}}</ref>
==Israeli venture capital industry== {{main article|Venture capital in Israel}} [[File:Madpis.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Jerusalem Venture Partners]] (JVP) compound in [[Jerusalem]], one of Israel's largest Venture Capital firms.]] The origins of the now thriving venture capital industry in Israel can be traced to a government initiative in 1993 named the Yozma program ("Initiative" in Hebrew); which offered attractive tax incentives to any foreign venture-capital investments in Israel and offered to double any investment with funds from the government.<ref name=Gilder>{{Citation | title = Silicon Israel — How market capitalism saved the Jewish state | url = http://www.city-journal.org/2009/19_3_jewish-capitalism.html | author = Gilder, George | journal = City Journal -Summer 2009 | volume = 19 | issue = 3 | accessdate = 11 November 2009 }}</ref> As a result, Between 1991 and 2000, Israel's annual venture-capital outlays, nearly all private, rose nearly 60-fold, from $58 million to $3.3 billion; companies launched by Israeli venture funds rose from 100 to 800; and Israel's information-technology revenues rose from $1.6 billion to $12.5 billion. By 1999, Israel ranked second only to the United States in invested private-equity capital as a share of GDP. And it led the world in the share of its growth attributable to high-tech ventures: 70 percent.<ref name="Gilder"/>
Israel's thriving venture capital industry has played an important role in financing and funding Silicon Wadi. The [[financial crisis of 2007-2010]] affected the availability of venture capital locally. In 2009, there were 63 [[mergers and acquisitions]] in the Israeli market worth a total of $2.54 billion; 7% below 2008 levels ($2.74 billion), when 82 Israeli companies were merged or acquired, and 33% lower than 2007 proceeds ($3.79 billion) when 87 Israeli companies were merged or acquired.<ref name=VC>[http://www.investinisrael.gov.il/NR/exeres/A19A138D-87A7-416B-8D62-1C968E035E13.htm Venture Capital in Israel] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060218080510/http://www.investinisrael.gov.il/NR/exeres/A19A138D-87A7-416B-8D62-1C968E035E13.htm |date=18 February 2006 }}</ref> Numerous high tech Israeli companies have been acquired by global corporations for its provision of reliable and quality corporate personnel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jfunders.org/sites/default/files/docs/events/briefing_book_final.pdf |title=FUNDING THE FUTURE: Advancing STEM in Israeli Education |publisher=STEM Israel |date=4 December 2012 |accessdate=18 March 2013 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Israel's venture capital industry has about 70 active venture capital funds, of which 14 international VCs with Israeli offices. Additionally, there are some 220 international funds, including [[Polaris Venture Partners]], [[Accel Partners]] and [[Greylock Partners]], that do not have branches in Israel, but actively invest in Israel through an in-house specialist.
In 2009, the [[life sciences]] sector led the market with $272 million or 24% of total capital raised, followed by the [[software]] sector with $258 million or 23%, the [[communications]] sector with $219 million or 20%, and the [[Internet]] sector with 13% of capital raised in 2009.<ref name="VC"/>
==Multinational technology companies operating in Israel== {{main article|List of multinational companies with research and development centres in Israel}} [[File:PikiWiki Israel 6737 Science and technology in Israel.jpg|thumb|250px| [[SanDisk]]'s Israel facility in [[Kfar Saba]]]] [[File:Park Azorim 023.jpg|thumb|250px|right|[[Marvell Technology Group|Marvell's]] development center in [[Petah Tikva]]]] [[File:Herzliya Ind 047.jpg|thumb|250px|right|[[CA Technologies]]' development center in [[Herzliya]]]] With such an impressive record for creating profit driven technology, Israel has become the top choice for many business leaders and high technology industry giants. As of 2010, more than 35,000 personnel are employed in multinationals research and development centers across Israel, making 'Silicon Wadi' a source for worldwide strategic technology development. In recent years, East Asian multinationals and investors, especially from Mainland China, have actively invested and opened up offices in Israel, including Chinese technology giants such as [[Alibaba Group|Alibaba]], [[Baidu]], [[Tencent]] and [[Kuang-Chi]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/07/18/china-is-increasingly-becoming-key-for-israels-high-tech-industry.html|title=China is increasingly becoming key for Israel's high-tech industry|last=Biedermann|first=Ferry|date=18 July 2017|work=CNBC|accessdate=}}</ref> Around 60 foreign R&D centers are engaged in a diverse range of activities including biotechnology, chemicals, industrial machinery, communication equipment, scientific instruments, medical devices, flash memory storage equipment, computer hardware components, software, semiconductors and internet. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! width="150" |Company !! width="110"|Year established in Israel !! width="110"|No of employees in Israel !! Major acquisitions in Israel |- | [[IBM]] || 1949 || 2,000 || [[Ubique (company)|Ubique]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Lotus Development Corp. to Bring Real-Time Dimension to Messaging and Groupware|url=http://www-03.ibm.com/press/us/en/pressrelease/2648.wss|date=19 May 1998}}</ref> [[I-Logix]],<ref>{{cite news |title=IBM Completes Acquisition of Telelogic AB |url=http://www-03.ibm.com/press/us/en/pressrelease/23792.wss |work=IBM Press room |publisher=IBM |date=3 April 2008 |accessdate=20 October 2009}}</ref> [[IBM XIV Storage System|XIV]],<ref>{{cite news |title=IBM acquires Israel-based XIV for undisclosed sum |date=2 January 2008 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/technology-media-telco-SP/idUSL0218975220080103|accessdate=16 March 2009 | work=Reuters}}</ref> Guardium,<ref>{{cite news|title=IBM to buy Israeli start-up company for $225 million|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/business/ibm-to-buy-israeli-start-up-company-for-225-million-1.3275|newspaper=Haaretz|date=27 November 2009}}</ref> Diligent Technologies,<ref>{{cite press release | title =IBM Acquires Storage Company Diligent Technologies | publisher = [[IBM]] | date =18 April 2008 | url =http://www-03.ibm.com/press/us/en/pressrelease/23929.wss | accessdate = 2 Flight Test Safety Award |image=Tony LeVier Flight Test Safety Award Trophy.jpg |imagesize=100px |caption=Tony LeVier Trophy |description=Contribution to flight test safety |presenter=The Society of Experimental Test Pilots; Gentex Corp. |location=Lancaster, California |country={{USA}} |year={{Start date|1999}} |website= [http://www.setp.org/criteria/tony-levier-flight-test-safety-award.html SETP] }} The '''Tony LeVier Flight Test Safety Award''', named in honor of [[test pilot]] [[Tony LeVier]], was established by the [[Flight Test Safety Committee]] to pay recognition to people who have significantly contributed to the safety of flight test operations. This annual award, which can be presented to an individual or team is presented by [[Gentex Corporation]] at the [[Society of Experimental Test Pilots]] at their annual awards banquet. To be considered for the award, nominees must have contributed in a significant way to the flight test safety community over a period of time. The nominee must have made a singular safety achievement involved in the saving of human life, a flight test program or test aircraft, and may be nominated only where safety rules were not broken. ==Past recipients== Recipients of the SETP Tony LeVier Flight Test Safety Award include:{{cite web|url=http://www.setp.org/winners/tony-levier-flight-test-safety-recipients.html |title=Tony LeVier Flight Test Safety Recipients |publisher=Society of Experimental Test Pilots |location=Lancaster, California |date= |accessdate=2015-10-10}} *1999 – [[Eric E. Fiore]], [[Bombardier Aerospace]] *2000 – [[Rodrigo J. Huete]], [[Federal Aviation Administration|FAA]] *2001 – David Houle, Former President of SFTE *2002 – [[Bruce A. Peterson]] *2003 – [[Auto ACAS Team]] *2004 – LCDR William Patton, Aviation Safety Officer and Program Manager and Mr. Thomas Roberts, Research, Development, Test, and Evaluation Safety Manager, Naval Test Wing Atlantic (NTWL) Safety Office *2005 – [[Ralph Mohr]] *2006 - Terry White *2007 - John E. Cashman *2008 - Flight Test Safety Database Team: Barton Henwood, [[NASA]]/[[Dryden Flight Research Center|DFRC]]; Rodrigo Huete, FAA (Ret); John Hed, FAA; Greg Lewis, [[National Test Pilot School]] *2009 - Jerry “Mac” McCawley, [[Lockheed Martin]] *2010 - Dave Downey *2011 - Thomas Roberts *2012 - The [[Boeing]] Company 787 Flight Test Team: Mike Carriker, Randy Neville, Jennifer-Ellen Gessler; [[Federal Aviation Administration]] 787 Flight Test Team: Eugene Arnold and John Hed *2013 - Art Tomassetti *2014 - Terry Lutz, [[Airbus]] *2015 - Larry Flynn, [[Gulfstream Aerospace]] *2016 - Warren A. Hansen, [[Textron Aviation]] *2017 - Mark Skoog, NASA [[Armstrong Flight Research Center]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==See also== *[http://www.flighttestsafety.org/awards Flight Test Safety Committee Page] *[http://www.setp.org/criteria/tony-levier-flight-test-safety-award.html SETP Criteria] *[http://www.setp.org/winners/tony-levier-flight-test-safety-recipients.html Recipient List] [[Category:Aviation awards]]

{{Infobox settlement |name = Umeda |native_name = |official_name = 梅田 |settlement_type = |image_skyline = Buildings in Umeda.jpg |image_caption = The Umeda skyline |image_map = |map_caption = |image_flag = |image_seal = |seal_size = |seal_link = |image_shield = |coordinates = {{coord|34|42|0|N|135|29|49.2|E|region:JP|display=inline,title}} |pushpin_map = Japan <!-- the name of a location map as per http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Location_map --> |pushpin_label_position = <!-- the position of the pushpin label: left, right, top, bottom, none --> |pushpin_map_caption = |pushpin_mapsize = |subdivision_type = Country |subdivision_name = Japan |subdivision_type1 = [[prefectures of Japan|Prefecture]] |subdivision_name1 = [[Osaka Prefecture]] |subdivision_type2 = [[cities in Japan|City]] |subdivision_name2 = [[Osaka]] |subdivision_type3 = [[wards of Japan|Ward]] |subdivision_name3 = [[Kita-ku, Osaka|Kita-ku]] |established_title = |established_date = |parts_type = |parts = |government_type = |leader_title = |leader_name = |area_footnotes = |area_total_km2 = |area_land_km2 = |area_water_km2 = |area_water_percent = |area_urban_km2 = |elevation_m = |population_demonym = |population_as_of = |population_footnotes = |population_total = |population_note = |population_density_km2 = |population_density_metro_km2 = |population_metro = |demographics_type1 = |demographics1_footnotes = |demographics1_title1 = |demographics1_info1 = |timezone = [[Japan Standard Time]] |utc_offset = +9 |postal_code_type = |postal_code = |area_code = |website = |footnotes = }} {{Nihongo|'''Umeda'''|梅田|lead=yes}} is a major commercial and business district in [[Kita-ku, Osaka|Kita-ku]], [[Osaka]], [[Japan]], and the city's main northern railway terminus ([[Ōsaka Station]], [[Umeda Station]]).
The area is notable for its comparatively high concentration of tall buildings, of which those in Nishi-Umeda, [[Dojima]] and [[Nakanoshima]] form a prominent [[skyscraper]] district.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?cityID=860|title=Osaka - SkyscraperPage.com|website=skyscraperpage.com}}</ref> Four of the city's largest department stores ([[Hanshin Department Store|Hanshin]], [[Hankyu]], [[Daimaru]], and [[Isetan]]) are located here, as well as popular shopping and tourist areas such as [[HEP Five]], Osaka Grand Front, and [[Umeda Sky Building]].
The district's name means "plum field".
In addition to being a major business district, Umeda offers a large selection of shopping, entertainment, and nightlife venues.

[[File:William Randolph II.JPG|thumb]] '''William Randolph II''' (November 1681{{mdash}}October 19, 1741), also known as '''William Randolph Jr.''' or '''Councillor Randolph''', was an American planter and politician. He was the [[State Treasurer|Treasurer]] of [[Colony of Virginia|Virginia]] and the oldest child of [[William Randolph]] and Mary Isham.<ref name="Page">{{cite book |last1=Page |first1=Richard Channing Moore |authorlink1= |last2= |first2= |authorlink2= |editor1-first= |editor1-last= |editor1-link= |others= |title=Genealogy of the Page Family in Virginia |trans-title=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cOBBAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_atb#v=onepage&q&f=false |archiveurl= |archivedate= |format= |accessdate= |type= |edition=2 |series= |volume= |year=1893 |month= |origyear= |publisher=Press of the Publishers Printing Co. |location=New York |language= |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |pages=249–272 |at= |trans-chapter=|chapter=Randolph Family |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=cOBBAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA247#v=onepage&q&f=false |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}</ref><ref name="Glenn">{{cite book |last1= |first1=|authorlink1= |last2= |first2= |authorlink2= |editor1-first=Thomas Allen |editor1-last=Glenn |editor1-link= |others= |title=Some Colonial Mansions: And Those Who Lived In Them : With Genealogies Of The Various Families Mentioned |trans-title=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iQkpAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_atb#v=onepage&q&f=false |archiveurl= |archivedate= |format= |accessdate= |type= |edition= |series= |volume=1 |date= |year=1898 |month= |origyear= |publisher=Henry T. Coates & Company |location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania |language= |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |page= |pages=430–459 |at= |trans-chapter=|chapter=The Randolphs: Randolph Genealogy |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=iQkpAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA433#v=onepage&q&f=false |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}</ref><ref name="Byrd">{{cite book |last1=Byrd |first1=William |authorlink1=William Byrd II |last2= |first2= |authorlink2= |editor1-first=Maude Howlett |editor1-last=Woodfin |editor1-link= |others= |title=Another Secret Diary of William Byrd of Westover, 1739–1741: With Letters & Literary Exercises, 1696–1726 |trans-title=|url= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |format= |accessdate= |type= |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |year=1942 |month= |origyear= |publisher=The Dietz Press |location=Richmond, Virginia |language= |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |page=57 |pages= |at= |trans-chapter=|chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}</ref>
==Biography and family== Randolph was born on the [[Turkey Island (James River)|Turkey Island Plantation]] along the [[James River]] in [[Henrico County, Virginia]] in 1681 and resided there his entire life.<ref name="Glenn"/> He married Elizabeth Beverley (the daughter of [[Peter Beverley]], a [[List of Speakers of the Virginia House of Burgesses|Speaker of the House of Burgesses]] and Treasurer of Virginia) around 1705 and the couple had five children that reached adulthood:<ref name="Page"/><ref name="Glenn"/><ref name="Standard">{{cite book |last1=Standard |first1=W.G. |authorlink1= |last2= |first2= |authorlink2= |editor1-first=Philip A. |editor1-last=Bruce |editor1-link=Philip Alexander Bruce |others= |title=The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography |trans-title=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cUf3xngIgoYC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_atb#v=onepage&q&f=false |archiveurl= |archivedate= |format= |accessdate= |type= |edition= |series= |volume=III |date= |year=1895 |month= |origyear= |publisher=The Virginia Historical Society |location=Richmond, Virginia |language= |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |page= |pages=169–170 |at= |trans-chapter=|chapter=Major Robert Beverley and His Descendants |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=cUf3xngIgoYC&pg=PA169#v=onepage&q&f=false |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|William Randolph II had seven children. Two of his earliest children, Beverely and William, died very young and their names were given to older children.<ref name="Wassell Randolph">{{cite book |last1=Randolph |first1=Wassell |authorlink1= |last2= |first2= |authorlink2= |editor1-first= |editor1-last= |editor1-link= |others= |title=William Randolph I of Turkey Island, Henrico County, Virginia: And His Immediate Descendants |trans-title=|url= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |format= |accessdate= |type= |edition= |series= |volume= |year=1949 |month= |origyear= |publisher=Seebode Mimeo Service; distributed by Cossitt Library |location= |language= |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |page=39 |pages=|at= |trans-chapter=|chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}</ref>|group="nb"}} *Beverley Randolph (born ~1706) married Elizabeth Lightfoot and had no children.<ref name="Robert Isham Randolph">{{cite book |last1=Randolph |first1=Robert Isham |authorlink1= |last2= |first2= |authorlink2= |editor1-first= |editor1-last= |editor1-link= |others= |title=The Randolphs of Virginia: A Compilation of the Descendants of William Randolph of Turkey Island and His Wife Mary Isham Of Bermuda Hundred |trans-title=|url=http://randolpharchives.org/books/Randolphs_of_Virginia_001-052.pdf |archiveurl= |archivedate= |format=PDF |accessdate= |type= |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |year=1936 |month= |origyear= |publisher= |location= |language= |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |page= |pages= |at= |trans-chapter=|chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}</ref> *Peter Randolph (born ~1708) married Robert Bolling Jr.'s daughter, Lucille Bolling. They had four children, including [[Beverley Randolph]], the [[List of Governors of Virginia|eighth]] [[Governor of Virginia]]<ref name="Page"/> and Ann Bolling Randolph Fitzhugh, [[William Fitzhugh]]'s wife.<ref name="Robert Isham Randolph"/> *William Randolph III (c. 1710–1762), owner of [[Wilton House Museum|Wilton]] plantation house, married Anne Harrison, the daughter of [[Benjamin Harrison IV]], and had five children.<ref name="Page"/> *Mary Randolph (1704–1777) married Joseph Rentfro <ref name="Page"/><ref name="Wassell Randolph"/> *Elizabeth "Betty" Randolph (born ~1725) married Colonel [[John Chiswell]] and had at least four daughters who reached adulthood, including Susan R. Chiswell, the wife of [[John Robinson (Virginia)|John Robinson]], the 32nd [[List of Speakers of the Virginia House of Burgesses|Speaker of the House of Burgesses]].<ref name="Page"/>
Randolph was a great-uncle of [[President of the United States|United States President]] [[Thomas Jefferson]].
His brother, [[Richard Randolph]] married Major [[John Bolling]]'s daughter, Jane Bolling, also a [[lineal descendant]] of Pocahontas. They had six children.
His brother, [[Sir John Randolph]] married Susanna Beverley (daughter of [[Peter Beverley]], Speaker of the [[House of Burgesses]] and [[State Treasurer|Treasurer]] of [[Colony of Virginia|Virginia]]) on July 20, 1738.

==Westham, Virginia== The town of [[Westham, Virginia]] was established on land that had been owned by Randolph.<ref name="Hendricks">{{cite book |last1=Hendricks |first1=Christopher E. |authorlink1= |last2= |first2= |authorlink2= |editor1-first= |editor1-last= |editor1-link= |others= |title=The Backcountry Towns of Colonial Virginia |trans-title=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9af3Sm3hUpAC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_atb#v=onepage&q&f=false |archiveurl= |archivedate= |format= |accessdate= |type= |edition= |series= |volume= |year=2006 |month= |origyear= |publisher=University of Tennessee Press |location=Knoxville, Tennessee |language= |isbn=9781572335431 |oclc= |doi= |id= |page= |pages=40–44 |at= |trans-chapter=|chapter=The Piedmont |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=9af3Sm3hUpAC&lpg=PA20&pg=PA66#v=onepage&q&f=false |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}</ref> When Randolph died, his son Beverley inherited Westham Plantation and planned to create the town of Westham on part of it to facilitate trade in the [[Piedmont region of Virginia]].<ref name="Hendricks"/> After Beverley's sudden death, Peter Randolph inherited his brother's land and completed work on the project – renaming the town "Beverley" in honor of his older brother – with help from [[William Cabell (American Revolution)|William Cabell]] and [[Peter Jefferson]].<ref name="Hendricks"/> Jefferson was one of a number of important Virginians, including [[Carter Braxton]], [[Joshua Fry]], [[Jon Blair Hunter|John Hunter]], [[Robert S. Rose|Robert Rose]], and [[William Stith]]. who purchased lots in the new town.<ref name="Hendricks"/> Peter Randolph eventually sold Westham Plantation to his younger brother, William, who in turn sold the property to [[William Byrd III]].<ref name="Hendricks"/>
